utterances: (SOUNDBITE OF MOVIE, ""PIN UP GIRL"")
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""DON'T CARRY TALES OUT OF SCHOOL"")
(As Lorry Jones) (Singing) Don't carry tales out of school 'cause if you do, you're a fool.
We're going to backtrack, I guess.
You want to hear about our adventures.
That's my grandma, and this is the story of a trip she took in 1939 with her best friend, Dorothy.
That little trip became a big-screen musical called ""Pin Up Girl"" starring Betty Grable.
Before Dorothy died in August, she and my grandma told this story hundreds of times.
Well, we remember a lot for old ladies, don't we?
That was Dorothy.
Dorothy Fiedelman.
I'm a friend of Betty Jane's.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
I'm 87, is that right?
You are.
And I'm Betty Jane Simmons.
I'm 87 years old.
I'm older than Dorothy, one month older than Dorothy.
And how long have you known each other?
I was at her fifth birthday party.
We were little girls.
This story begins a few years later.
They were 18 when they climbed aboard a train in Denver, their hometown, bound for the East Coast.
They'd been invited to a formal dance called Ivy Ball in Philadelphia.
At the dance, at the Ivy Ball, it was a big deal.
We were in formals, and the boys were in tuxes.
So what kind of dancing were you doing?
Ballroom, jitterbug.
Well, since whatever, to the music.
They do that now, still.
The guy puts his arm around you.
You put your head on his shoulder.
No, not really.
Oh.
Anyway, back to Ivy Ball.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
Frank Sinatra, who was just beginning to get famous, sang.
I looked at him.
We danced by him.
He was so skinny he was hiding behind the microphone.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
I couldn't believe that anybody would think this guy was wonderful.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""YOU AND I"")
(Singing) Darling, you and I know the reason why a summer sky is blue.
The girls were screaming.
They were screaming (unintelligible).
And they literally did think he was the greatest.
Well, we got to see him.
We weren't impressed.
They weren't impressed.
So Frank Sinatra was a bust.
(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, ""PIN UP GIRL"")
(Lorry Jones) Well, that's our first thrill.
Let's go look for another one.
Grandma and Dorothy went looking for a thrill in New York, at the nightclubs they'd read about for years, the elegance, the music, the celebrities.
We didn't have any nightclubs in Denver.
So Betty and I had a couple of days.
We decided we wanted to see these places, but we didn't have the money.
And nobody was going to take us.
Unidentified Man #1: (As character) I'm sorry, Mademoiselle, It's regular table.
For this evening, all tables are taken.
(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, ""PIN UP GIRL"")
So they came up with a plan to get in with no money and no escort.
We get there just before the show.
My name was Bomash(ph), and it was an unusual name, so we decided to say we were looking for Mr. Bomash's party.
So we'd go in just before, and we'd say, Mr. Bomash's party, please, and just then, the lights would go off, and they'd say: Well, you'll have to sit down.
So we sit down, and we watch the entertainment.
And stay very still.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
We expected to be invited out, and we got away with it.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
So we left, and then we'd go on another place, and we'd do the same thing.
We went to about three different New York nightclubs, the ultimate adventure, and I kept thinking: I can't believe this is a dream.
I'm living a dream.
The whole time, I'll never forget that feeling.
